header.title: Mum ‘blacked up’ to go to 80s party dressed as Prince
header.postText: A mother has found herself at the centre of a race row after she was kicked out of an 80s tribute night for ‘blacking up’ as pop icon Prince.', 'Catherine McBride, 47, insisted she wasn’t racist and said it was a ‘bit of fun’ after she painted her face in dark foundation to resemble the singer.', 'But staff at Glasgow’s Pavilion Theatre asked her to take off the make-up or leave the 80s Mania event after receiving complaints.', 'The mother, of Pollock, Glasgow, told the Daily Record the incident ruined her night, which she had been enjoying with nine of her friends who were also in fancy dress – although no one else had painted their face.', 'She told the news site: ‘I was only trying to have a laugh and would never have deliberately set out to cause any offence to anyone.’', 'McBride claimed a worker on the door of the Pavilion said she liked her fancy dress and they had a laugh about it, before other party-goers inside asked to take photos with her.', 'She said she had no idea there was anything wrong and sat down to enjoy the show.', 'But soon a member of theatre management took her to one side and said six punters had complained after being offended by her ‘blacked up’ costume.', 'She told the Daily Record: ‘I’ve worn the exact same outfit before at a friend’s birthday party in a local pub and nobody said a word. I was totally taken aback when all of this happened.’', 'McBride said she rubbed off the make-up with kitchen roll and questioned why staff didn’t say something when she first entered the theatre.', 'She claimed hundreds were at the event but ‘only six complained’ and said it was ‘a bit of an overreaction’.', 'The mother added she thought it was a ‘bit out of order’ and thinks people took it the wrong way.', 'Zandra Yeaman, of the Coalition for Racial Equality and Rights, said the history of blackface is ‘rooted in racist bigotry and is a legacy of slavery’ and people should be more aware of how offensive it is.', 'Pavilion general manager Iain Gordon said: ‘We received complaints and didn’t want the situation to escalate. We decided to ask the individual to remove the make-up, which she agreed to do.’
header.socioLingVar: Ethnicity - General,Ethnicity - Black,Age - Youngsters,Gender - General,Age - General,Nationality - European or anti-Europeans

Why oh why can't people just tell them to eff off and just carry on doing what they were doing!If it had been me they would have had to have dragged my dead body out of there before I removed myself. There was nothing wrong with the outfit

commentThread.commentText: The outfit she wore isn't what's caused offence, it's that she used make up to make herself darker. You can dress up as your icon without doing that. As it has been said what she did is rooted in bigotry from centuries ago. It's insensitive at best and incredibly racist at the worst.

replies.commentText: Manj Pal Kaur White people seem to have a hard time understanding this exact point. She could have been Prince without the black face especially since Prince wasn't even dark complected and closer to caucasian in skin tone. White people are tired of the "Race Card" well ..Black people are tired of police being acquitted for killing us, inequality and Politicians that don't represent us. We'll get over it when certain whites get over it

Like you said, rooted in history "from centuries ago" people need to move on and put that behind us. The days of the black and white minstels are well gone. Are you saying that it is offensive to want to portray a figure of an another race even if you idolise them and put them on a pedestal? Would it b e racist if a black person put make up on that made them look like a white person? I wouldnt take offence. And its not racist in the least, what woul d be racist would be turning up dressed as John McClane in the scene from Die Hard With A Vengence where he is made to walk through Harlem wearing a sandwich board which reads "I Hate -----------". Now that wou ld be racist and highly inappropriate

I have to say that enough time hasn't passed enough for it to be OK and yes if someone were to 'white up' I would react the same and I would hope everyone would as well. I practice what I preach. Case in point, there is an Indian word to describe white people and it has negative, dare I say it racist connotations, and I refuse to use it or even have it be used in my presence because it is offensive. Like I said she was insensitive at best and I hope she has learned from it.

It's always easier for the priveleged to tell the less fortunate to move on and get over it, easier for the rich to tell the poor get a job and pay your Bills on time. White people weren't slaves for centuries and even in this day and age , White people are fortunate enough to get leniency within the judicial system that is not made equally for Blacks and Whites alike. White Privilege allows women to be raped and the offender receives no jail time while Blacks get jail time for enrolling kids into schools in a different district or shot by police for no reason while those cops are acquitted but yet a black police officer is convicted for killing a whit e woman. Blacks will gladly move on when we are given the same respect, opportunities and privileges Whites are given

Manj Pal Kaur Seriously call me the indian word for white people, I really couldnt give a crap what you refer to me as! The fact is that the "rasict" card gets pulled more and more frequently these days. I was watching the news today and theres a christian church in yorkshire that on a Friday has an agreement with the muslim community to use the church as a place for them to conduct their Friday prayer and you know something, I was acutually so pleased that this was happening.

Robert Bruce Calm down, I wasn't having a go. I thought we were having a civilised discussion. You may not care abt that word but I do. I was just saying that I talk the talk and walk the walk. I'm a fair individual. I am glad that there is great community spirit where you are and that humanity prevails. The world can learn from this. Hope you're having a lovely evening. Take Care.

From the tone of your writing I would say that you my son have a chip on your shoulder and could in fact be a racist yourself! However the phrase White Privilege does not offend me, it just makes me laugh at how other races see us "whites". Let me guess, you think we all live in 42 room mansions with servants and staff to wait on us hand and foot and we all go out on the boxing day shoot in our Range Rovers, and pay little Timmy 50p to keep the dogs on the leads until its time to go home for tea and scones

Manj Pal Kaur Maybe you mistook what I was saying, I was not directing the comment "call me what you want" at you, maybe I should have phrased it differently. I do know it wasnt directed at me :). It was more a statement saying that for me I dont care if someone calls me a name because of my colour, race, or religion because to me it doesnt matter, its just a word. To me, in an ideal world people would be able to impersonate people to a degree without any offence being intended, and that goes for everyone and in all directions. I just feel the world has got to a point that nobody can do anything without someone taking offence. Dont get me wrong there needs to be boundries but would I get offended if an American or Austrailian or Canadian turned up to a party dressed as William Wallace with bright ginger hair and wearing a kilt and sporren carrying a haggis? - no I would just laugh and take the piss out of their country in some way shape or form. Thats the problem though many people have become so bitter towards people who intend no actual harm and intend no offence, and to be fair I think anyone with any brains can tell the difference between harmless banter and deep roote d racism.

You must be out of your tiny narrow mind. It is blindingly obvious that the black face was an intrinsic part of the fancy dress outfit and not in any way racist. It implies that anyone who is offended by this must be ashamed of their ow n race if they happen to not be white.

Devon Sol , So you think she should pretend that Prince was white? That probably would be offensive. Prince was black, she was attending an 80's fancy dress party as Prince. It's as simple as that. Don't try to make it into something it's not.

What I'm trying to say is that we really don't know if she is racist or not i.e. we're not mind readers but I'm giving her the benefit of the doubt to say she's most likely just insensitive and not realising how it wouls come across. We are in the age of being mindful and being considerate and that just comes with being a decent human being. Now she knows and hopefully something positive can come from this.

I respectfully suggest you have a rethink about your views. If she had gone as Prince but turned him into a white person then I could understand why someone might take offence. Don't you get that?

Mark Thompson That is not the same as what she did was imitate someone. I get your point, though.

Devon Sol White slavery, white slave trade, and white slave traffic refer to the chattel slavery of White Europeans by non-Europeans (such as North Africans and the Muslim world), as well as by Europeans themselves, such as the Viking thralls or European Galley slaves. From Antiquity, European slaves were common during the reign of Ancient Rome and were prominent during the Ottoman Empire into the early modern period. In Feudalism, there were various forms of status below the Freeman that is known as Serfdom (such as the bordar, villein, vagabond and slave) which could be bought and sold as property and were subject to labor and branding by their owners or demense. Under Muslim rule, the Arab slave trades that included Caucasian captives were often fueled by raids into European territories or were taken as children in the form of a blood tax from the families of citizens of conquered territories to serve the empire for a variety of functions. In the mid-19th century, the term 'white slavery' was used to describe the Christian slaves that were sold into the Barbary slave trade. Slavery isn't a race thing it's a class thing rich vs poor.

Somalians use to come in the pup with their own crates and play cards my dad tried to get them out one night night and was putt in a coma for a weeks do I dwell on it no, did I become a new nazi no, am I racist no, every colour is capable of the same disgusting ways, the same ignorance the same bias, and guess what my dads best mate for 40 years was Jamaican and guess what he despised Somalians.

But statistically Blacks beating whites as Hate Crimes, blacks beating the judicial system and getting off are miniscual in comparison to my caucasian counterparts. If you don't think White Privilege exist then you're sheltered or living under a rock and if you think only rich white men are privileged then think again. Enjoy your Tea and Scones

In this day and age, if you reside in the U.S.A, my argument is based on the large scale of inequality towards minorities and in regards to this post, I understand the desire to want to blacken your face as a white person in order to look like a celebrity you idolize or whatever but I don't have to like or agree with it, especially because of the true meaning behind it used in the 1930's until now in order to demonize and insult Blacks as a whole. Just my 2 cents

Robert Bruce  This i something that happened in the 60s 70s 80s 90s and the new century. When white people stop we'll stop bringing it up. Its been more than a couple of centuries since it started you've all had enough time to find a new joke.

David Marsden Ignorant reply. She darkened her skin darker than Prince actually was. so who was she dressing up as? Black face has been used for centuries to mock black people. In fact in my lifetime I watched th e Black and white minstrels on TV. Its still an insult as far as we're concerned, so just because you don't think it is doesn't mean we should put up with it.

commentThread.commentText: Totally OTT by the venue.

Blacking up a face is offensive as it takes us back to times where it was used for entertainment and ‘comedy’ value. However you shouldn’t confuse mocking an entire race, creed or culture with simple ‘dressing up’ as a black individual. Providing the outfit or make up isn’t offensive (ie over stating certain perceived characteristics to demean the person in colour) it is just fancy dress.. it’s two very different things.

replies.commentText: If you say so.
Angel Sam Pattison-O'Brien should i be offended by this ?
No... it’s not someone colouring their face to demean or humiliate someone ... it’s not a difficult concept

commentThread.commentText: Why o why would people intentionally blacken their face in the first place if it wasn’t for fun, why do people play the racist card all the time, should we complain if we see a clowns face painted white on a not so white face, should we comment on all fake tan lovers, thank heavens most of the pits have closed those poor miners wouldn’t stand a chance these days, political correctness does my head in, get a life the people who complain about this, it’s the likes of you people who bring th e racist aspect into everyday life, we are all human beings let’s forget about colour and live as one.

Hahaha. you got to see the irony in the people on here defending racism... they are are more offended at other people being offended than those people being offended in the first place... and they complain as if someone punched their mother. How can you even complain about someone being offended with such anger and offense in your own complaint... its ironic really!

replies.commentText: David Sinclaire, the point is, nobody on here is defending racism because there was n o racism to defend.

So if a 'black' person uses bleach/fading creams to lighten their skin, is that offensive to a white person? No, see the foolishness here? We are all human, lets get on with being human.

Sarah-Louise Douglas I am actually very aware of black history. But I am also aware that we live in a world where everybody is 'offended' by being different to a majority. It's our diversity and unity that gives us our greatest strength. Being offended by' makeup' at a party is laughable and pathetic in the face of more complex issues that effect us all globally.

Six gutless pricks go and 'tell the teacher'. If the gutless pricks were so offended why didn't they discuss the issue with the lady?

It would appear that the bleating PC brigade can read racism into just about anything. She was dressed as Prince and Prince had dark skin. If she had gone as a womble, would the animial rights people have complained about the use of fake fur?

replies.commentText: So would you find it acceptable, for example, for a white actor to black up to play Othello? Or Nelson Mandela?

Tony Cowdrill - If the role called for it yes, The Hunchback of Notre Dame would look unconvincing without a lump on his back but disability groups don't complain because the actor is portraying a character rather than making a racist statement. There are numerous fancy dress costumes that could cause offence, I imagine Miss Piggy could upset a few vegans and veggies.

commentThread.commentText: Not all white people are priveledged not in history and not in modern day, it is racist to say so, belittling and shows an ignorance to the multi faceted nature of history, race and slavery excuse the saying but it just not as simply not a s black and white as that. It's used as a way of controlling others, branding someone a racidt without even knowing them just judging them on your rules of what they can and can't do.Racism goes both ways and instead of keep pointing fingers and looking for someone to put down, why not focus on being a better person yourself.

Would the management act similarly if there was a production of Shakespeare's tragedy, Othelo being staged?...Othelo the Moor was similarly coloured. I use the word 'coloured' deliberately because it is the politically correct term for no n black / white people in South Africa, particularly the Western Cape. I was married to a coloured lady who would have gone beserk if referred to as 'black' and I knew many black people who felt the same about being ca lled 'coloured.' When can we get back to being 'people' and 'iindividuals'?

Oh yes, I forgot...I wonder how the critics would handle the annual parade / holiday / festival in Cape Town on 2nd January - known as 'Tweede Nuwe Jaar, where COLOURED people BLACK up their faces as Minstrels and parade through the streets...no one complains...they just have a good time.

In the BBC comedy Come Fly With Me there were characters Taaj and Precious who were blacked up and I didnt recall any complaint. It's trendy to jump on the bandwagon and cry racist for zero reason. if I wanted to fancy dress as an early 80's Michael Jackson I'm not going to look much like him if I dont paint my face ffs!

Cue all the brexit voters saying how ridiculous this is. Bloody brainless morons that feel so threatened about the fact its no longer considered acceptable to black up, just get over yourselves and stop whingeing.

replies.commentText: You and you're brexit voters are racists bs again. Go and walk round the likes of Lambeth late at night see how far you're pc attitude gets you.
Allan Kinsella no I'm not particularly PC, I just don't go round being a **** to people. Not sure how the lambeth comment is relevant to anything

Robert Jones did you not see the black man commenting above trerry Charles he isn't offended by it yet you a White man thinks he can argue against him, that is far more racist. So are you going to tell him he is wrong to see the funny side. Look mate you're not offended it's just an opportunity for you to virtue signal. Deal with issues that effect you. Because you can't tell a black man what he should or shouldn't find offensive.

Allan Kinsella Ive not read the comment and don't really care what he thinks. And I'm not offended at all, I'm just saying everyone knows not ok to black up these days. Yes there are some things we're not 'meant' to do that are worth taking a stand over but blacking up isn't one of them. At the end of the day it's one stupid woman in fancy dress yet dozens of people are feeling personally attacked and threatened by the fact she got asked to take he r black face makeup off.
Robert Jones Yes she should, we are not a costume for white people to parade, it is offensive, how can you not get it?

Shelaina Palmer yes I agree, I was trying to make the point (perhaps not articulately enough) that the people who are acting the most offended here are those supporting the continued 'right' to black up.

commentThread.commentText: I would have said no and then asked them to prove what law I had broken by dressing up in fancy dress. If they had tried to remove me then I would have called the police myself as they would in fact be acting illegally themselves if they removed me. In a club they only have the authority to put their hands on someone else to remove them if the crime warrants the force but being that it wouldn’t have been a crime 🤷‍♀️....well no leg to stand on really 🤷‍♀️No loss, no harm, no injury.....well except a few snowflakes melting anyway 😂

replies.commentText: In short you would have acted like an utter idiot, caused a huge scene and ruined the night for yourself and others because blacking up was so important to you.

commentThread.commentText: It’s 2019 and we are still having this conversation. That’s disappointing. I also take it that most of you felt Danny Baker did nothing wrong. Just think about how this impacts on others. Watch this and consider the ramifications of such actions: [LINK]

replies.commentText: She never once mentioned in the article that Prince was her hero, stop lying!
